title: Cannot detect post media type. Skip
[BUG] Tries to lookup and follow non-existent users
body:
This bug seems to occur when using the follow feature where users who liked a post in feed will be interacted with. However, it seems like InstaPy tries to follow a random label that is scraped from the webpage (like the date of a post).

## Expected Behavior
InstaPy only looks up profiles of real people and not other elements on page.

## Current Behavior
```
[xxx]  Got 4 likers shuffled randomly whom you can follow:
['www', 'yyy', 'SEPTEMBER 30', 'zzz']
...
[xxx]  Failed to get followers count of 'b'SEPTEMBER 30''  ~empty list
[xxx]  Failed to get following count of 'b'SEPTEMBER 30''  ~empty list
[xxx]  User: 'SEPTEMBER 30'  |> followers: unknown  |> following: unknown  |> relationship ratio: unknown
[xxx]  ~could not check if profile is public or private
[xxx]  --> Not a valid user: --> Sorry, could not check if profile is public or private
```

## Possible Solution (optional)

Better scraping and filtering of possible users to follow.

title: [BUG] Invalid xpath causes interact_by_comments to land in non exception else statement.
body:
## Expected Behavior
When using the `interact_by_comments` method, the app should iterate on a post's comments identifying the like and dislike buttons in search for replies.
## Current Behavior
The current logic gap causes the app to not be able to identify the like/dislike button hence failing to the else statement located at https://github.com/timgrossmann/InstaPy/blob/master/instapy/comment_util.py#L314-L315
## Possible Solution (optional)
Fix the xpath in https://github.com/timgrossmann/InstaPy/blob/master/instapy/xpath_compile.py#L79-L80 to the new paths.
## InstaPy configuration
example [here](https://instapy.org/actions/#usage) :
```
session.set_use_meaningcloud(enabled=True, license_key='', polarity="P")
session.set_use_yandex(enabled=True, API_key='', match_language=True, language_code="en")

session.set_do_comment(enabled=True, percentage=14)
session.set_comment_replies(replies=[u"😎😎😎", u"😁😁😁😁😁😁😁💪🏼"], media="Photo")

session.set_user_interact(amount=2, percentage=70, randomize=False, media="Photo")
session.set_do_like(enabled=True, percentage=100)

explicit_wait ignores timeout on "VOEL"
body:
in get_following_status we look for follow button with 7 - 14 set in timeout, but this function ignores it.
```
def explicit_wait(browser, track, ec_params, logger, timeout=35):
    """
    Explicitly wait until expected condition validates

    :param browser: webdriver instance
    :param track: short name of the expected condition
    :param ec_params: expected condition specific parameters - [param1, param2]
    :param logger: the logger instance
    """
    # list of available tracks:
    # <https://seleniumhq.github.io/selenium/docs/api/py/webdriver_support/
    # selenium.webdriver.support.expected_conditions.html>

    if not isinstance(ec_params, list):
        ec_params = [ec_params]

    # find condition according to the tracks
    if track == "VOEL":
        elem_address, find_method = ec_params
        ec_name = "visibility of element located"

        find_by = (By.XPATH if find_method == "XPath" else
                   By.CSS_SELECTOR if find_method == "CSS" else
                   By.CLASS_NAME)
        locator = (find_by, elem_address)
        condition = ec.visibility_of_element_located(locator)

    elif track == "TC":
        expect_in_title = ec_params[0]
        ec_name = "title contains '{}' string".format(expect_in_title)

        condition = ec.title_contains(expect_in_title)

    # generic wait block
    try:
        wait = WebDriverWait(browser, timeout)
        result = wait.until(condition)

    except TimeoutException:
        logger.info("Timed out with failure while explicitly waiting until {}!\n"
                    .format(ec_name))
        return False

    return result
```
Or am I missing something ?

Go to the specified user account and follow 50 followers with 10 mins delay between ~10 users. Repeat this every hour.

from instapy import InstaPy

insta_password = 'XXXXX'

title: Multiple comments on same image in same session.
body:
## Description of issue
While commenting, script will occasionally comment on the same image twice in a row. This occurs both when randomize is true or false. The instance shown used two comments from the clarifai_check_img_for function. Code and log posted below (including my little timer script).

I noticed a line in the log which reads: Given amount not fullfilled, image pool reached its end
I'm not sure exactly what that means, but that may be part of the problem.

## Expected Behavior
Script should only comment once per image

## Current Behavior
Occasionally comments twice

## Possible Solution (optional)
create an exit function which closes about this image immediately after commenting

## InstaPy configuration
```
from instapy import InstaPy
import time

start = time.time()
insta_username = 'MYUSERNAME'
insta_password = 'MYPASSWORDGOESHERE'

session = InstaPy(username=insta_username,
                  password=insta_password,
                  headless_browser=True,
                  multi_logs=True)

rawdontunfollow = open("DoNotUnfollow.csv")
dontunfollow = rawdontunfollow.read()

"""Setup"""
session.login()
session.set_dont_include(dontunfollow)
session.set_do_follow(enabled=False)
session.set_do_comment(enabled=True, percentage=10)
session.set_comments([':fire: :japanese_ogre: :fire:', ':fist:', ':thumbsup:', ':jack_o_lantern:'])
session.set_use_clarifai(enabled=True, api_key='MYAPIKEY')
session.clarifai_check_img_for(['tattoo'], comment=True, comments=['nice work!', 'rad', ':fire:'])
session.clarifai_check_img_for(['tattooart'], comment=True, comments=['nice work!', 'so cool', ':thumbsup:'])
session.clarifai_check_img_for(['traditionaltattoos'], comment=True, comments=['awesome', 'rad', 'wow'])
session.clarifai_check_img_for(['traditionaltattoos', 'dragon'], comment=True, comments=['amazing work!', ':japanese_ogre:', ':fire:'])
session.set_user_interact(amount=2, percentage=25, randomize=False)

"""Execute"""
session.like_by_tags(['tattooart', 'dotwork', 'blackwork'], amount=10, interact=True)

session.end()

"""Timer"""

rawruntime = end - start
runtime = rawruntime

title: If follow request has been sent to private account, unfollow behaviour is incorrect
body:
If InstaPy has sent a follow request to a private account, and then tries to unfollow that account while the request is still pending, the user will simply be deleted from the follow pool, which means that if the follow request is approved later, that user will never be automatically unfollowed by InstaPy if `onlyInstapyFollowed`is true.

## Expected Behavior

Pending follow request should be handled better than simply removing the user from the pool.

## Current Behavior

The user is deleted from the follow pool and will not be unfollowed in the future.

## Possible Solution (optional)

Identify that a follow request is pending. Either do nothing for now, and try unfollowing again later. Or delete the pending request. Perhaps the best solution would be a combination of both. Add a configuration flag for how long to wait for pending requests, such as three days or something like that. If the request was sent within that time period, ignore the user. If the time period has elapsed, then remove the follow request.

The problem is here, after the unfollow button could not be identified (because it's not yet available): https://github.com/timgrossmann/InstaPy/blob/master/instapy/unfollow_util.py#L118

title: Delete line from file - > error/PC down can cause the file to be malformed. (should use temp file)
body:
under util.py delete_line_from_file is not safe to use.
Please change it to the following:

````
def delete_line_from_file(filepath, lineToDelete, logger):
    try:
        filepathOld = filepath+".old"
        filepathTemp = filepath+".temp"

        f = open(filepath, "r")
        lines = f.readlines()
        f.close()

        f = open(filepathTemp, "w")
        for line in lines:
            if line != lineToDelete:
                f.write(line)
            else:
                print("123")
        f.close()

        # File leftovers that should not exist, but if so remove it
        try:
            os.remove(filepathOld)
        except:
            pass
        # rename original file to _old
        os.rename(filepath, filepathOld)
        # rename new temp file to filepath
        os.rename(filepathTemp, filepath)
       # remove old and temp file
        os.remove(filepathOld)

    except BaseException as e:
        logger.error("delete_line_from_file error {}".format(str(e)))
````
*** Something improtant ***
Related to the file "userX_followedPool.csv", it contain many usernames without ',' at the end of the line before the \n.
Maybe an old syntex leftovers? it results in not removing the username from list after unfollowing it !!!!

title: Unable to get username on like_by_feed - empty username
body:
<!-- Is this a Feature Request ? Please, check out our Wiki first https://github.com/timgrossmann/InstaPy/wiki -->
## Expected Behavior
The like_by_feed feature with Interact=True should be able to navigate through the user's profile and like a given amount of their pictures, then go back to the feed and keep liking.
## Current Behavior
I've been having an issue where the bot was getting an empty ('') username so it wasn't able to retrieve images from the user:
```
--> Image Liked!
--> User followed: ['']
Username [1/1]
--> b''
Getting   image list...
Interaction begin...
```
## Working Solution
I was able to debug the code and see the problem was in the "find_element_by_xpath()" function that retrieves the profile name in the feed. Looking at the HTML code of the page it seems the "a" tag with the title attribute is one level deeper, therefore you need to add another "div" to the path, and change the code as follows in line 1295, instapy.py:
FROM
`username = (self.browser.
                                 find_element_by_xpath(
                                                              "//main//div//div//article"
                                                              "//header//div//a"))`
TO
`username = (self.browser.find_element_by_xpath(
                                                    "//main//div//div//article"
                                                    "//header//div//div//a"))`

Hope this helps other people as well.

title: Docker all_in_one building issue
body:
## Expected Behavior
Build docker immage with all components successfully

## Current Behavior
Build failed:
`
dpkg: dependency problems prevent configuration of google-chrome-stable:
 google-chrome-stable depends on lsb-release; however:
  Package lsb-release is not installed.
`

## Possible Solution (optional)
dpkg will failed on first unmet dependecies. This dependecies should be fixed by `apt-get install -y -f`, but it won't be executed as dpkg returns non-zero code.

It can be fixed by:
`apt-get install -y -f ./google-chrome-stable_current_amd64.deb`

see: https://github.com/bsnisar/InstaPy/pull/1

## InstaPy configuration
clone repository and `docker build -t instapy ./docker_conf/all_in_one`

>     ActionChains(browser).move_to_element(login_elem).click().perform()

>     self.driver.execute(Command.W3C_ACTIONS, enc)

>     self.error_handler.check_response(response)

>     raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace)
> selenium.common.exceptions.MoveTargetOutOfBoundsException: Message: (417, 619) is out of bounds of viewport width (720) and height (469)
> 

## Possible Solution (optional)
Fixed this quickly by changing the launch resolution on instapy.py line 54:
`self.display = Display(visible=0, size=(800, 600))`
`self.display = Display(visible=0, size=(1900, 1200))`

## InstaPy configuration

Raspberry Pi 3, Raspbian Stretch Lite (2017-09-07 release)
Mozilla Firefox 52.4.0 (firefox-esr)
Selenium 3.6.0
Pyvirtualdisplay 0.2.1
Xvfb

Running with Python 3, nogui=True and use_firefox=True.


My solution isn't probably the best one, but it worked for me.
Maybe for some reason Display() doesn't launch correctly sized viewport?
Another solution could be to launch the browser maximized?

title: instapy.py: checked_img is an undefined name
body:
https://github.com/timgrossmann/InstaPy/blob/master/instapy/instapy.py#L708

__checked_img__ is an undefined name in this context. It is defined as a local variable in several other functions/methods but it is not defined until 50 lines later in this method, interact_by_users().  Undefined names can raise NameError at runtime.

This issue can be seen in: https://travis-ci.org/timgrossmann/InstaPy/jobs/283931737#L500

title: Firefox xpath selectors for "Followers" / "Following" + dialog boxes not working
body:
Hi everyone,

I set up the InstaPy bot for Chrome and Firefox yesterday and almost everything went easy / is running smooth (very good explanations and help here - thanks a mill!).

The only issue I face is that the xpath selectors can't find the followers / following elements in Firefox - see the following console excerpt. It seems like the selectors are able to alomst locate the right element on the page, because a gray box appears around the e.g. "followers" in the browser before the script crashes, but it's definetly not getting selected/clicked, as not dialog box with followers opens.

**Exception stack** - very last lines - the whole stack is quite long:
`\Python\lib\site-packages\selenium\webdriver\remote\errorhandler.py", line 194, in check_response raise exception_class(message, screen, stacktrace) selenium.common.exceptions.NoSuchElementException: Message: Unable to locate element: //div[text()='Followers' or text()='Following']/following-sibling::div`

I worked thru the exception stack and probably located the functions in unfollow_util.py which trigger the exception. But with all my amateur webcoding knowhow I wasn't able to fix the issue myself... sorry.

I am using the .follow_users_followers() function in the above mentioned case, but the same issues seems to prevent the .set_do_follow() to work (only strange thing is that this function call does not trigger any exception - it simply doesn't work and then the scripts runs till the end after liking photos, but without a single new follower).

This happened using Firefox 55.0.3 (64bit) version and Geckodriver v0.18.0-win64, as well as python 3.6.2-amd64.
Login, liking and pretty much everything else is working fine with the same setup - it really seems to be an issue with only this xpath command.
Furthermore everything is working fine with chrome... but for certain reasons I want to get firefox  to work, too ;)
(Unfortunatley I can't debug, push or pull at the moment).

Probably related issue: #607 

Thank you very much in advance!
sndf3

title: followers list are not loaded after certain number of people in the list, interact with someone else followers
body:
I could reproduce this problem almost every time. It seems to be a problem with the Instagram itself that is trying to prevent crawling on pages.
The case is if you use a list of more than 4-5 users in interact_user_followers() input array, the 5th and onward followers of the users in the list are not shown.
Instead the followers window opens with circling animation that shows it is trying to load them. Then this error appears on terminal log
('user_name') -> less users to follow than requested.

title: Pagination not working (I got a quick fix-- class was renamed)
body:
Hey the "load more" button class was renamed yielding this error: 'Load button not found, working with current images!'

The issue was a class name change for the "load more"button. I fixed my bot by updating instapy/like_util.py both lines 35 and 115 (they were identical) from:
('//a[contains(@class, "_8imhp _glz1g")]')

to:
('//a[contains(@class, "_1cr2e _epyes")]')

title: Exact match for negative Keywords
body:
It seems as if the function ```set_dont_like``` not only skips the selected hashtags but also skips all hashtags that starts with the selected hashtags. While this might be useful, too, I guess we should implement an exact match feature as well.

I stumbled upon this issue when I set "#me" as a negative keyword and images with hashtags like "#meindeutschland" wouldn’t be liked anymore.

title: UnicodeEncodeError: ordinal not in range(128)
body:
Seems like emoji aren’t working on my VPS:

```
File "/home/tibor/InstaPy/instapy/instapy.py", line 306, in like_by_tags
    commented += comment_image(self.browser, comments)
  File "/home/tibor/InstaPy/instapy/comment_util.py", line 17, in comment_image
    print(u'--> Commented: {}'.format(rand_comment))
UnicodeEncodeError: 'ascii' codec can't encode character u'\u270c' in position 23: ordinal not in range(128)
```

Does anyone has an idea why this isn’t working? 

On the Python FAQ I found [this quote](http://effbot.org/pyfaq/what-does-unicodeerror-ascii-decoding-encoding-error-ordinal-not-in-range-128-mean.htm):
> These messages usually means that you’re trying to either mix Unicode strings with 8-bit strings, or is trying to write Unicode strings to an output file or device that only handles ASCII.
When you do this, Python will usually assume that the 8-bit string contains ASCII data only, and will raise an error if this is not the case.

title: Process crashes on dead link/ if post has been deleted.
body:
> There are some deleted posts/ dead links when going through the to be liked pictures. Right now the process crashes when one of these pages shows up.

- [x] Fix the problem by catching the error and continuing with the other posts

title: Make InstaPy Language Independant
body:
#### Right now, InstaPy only works if your Instagram language is english. Make sure it works with any language (or at least, most)

- [x] change check if already likes from "Like" to something more generic
- [x] make sure there are no other areas of language problems
